Definition: Anything of value that you own, like cash, property, or investments.
Debts or obligations you owe, like loans, credit cards, or mortgages.
Your total assets minus your total liabilities.
A plan for how you spend and save your money.
Money set aside for unexpected expenses or emergencies.
A strategy to save money by putting savings first before spending.
Money left after paying for essential expenses.
Expenses that stay the same each month, like rent or car payments.
Expenses that can change each month, like groceries or gas.
A bank account that earns interest and helps you save money.
The cost of borrowing money or the money you earn on savings.
Interest calculated on both the original amount and any interest earned.
The actual return on savings over a year, including compound interest.
A number that shows how likely you are to repay your debts.
A type of credit score used by many lenders to assess credit risk.
Your total monthly debt payments divided by your monthly income.
The lowest amount you must pay on a debt each month.
Combining multiple debts into one with a single payment.
Negotiating with creditors to pay less than the total amount owed.
Professional advice to help manage and reduce debt.
A retirement savings account offered by employers with tax benefits.
A retirement account where you pay taxes up front, but withdrawals in retirement are tax-free.
A retirement account where you get a tax break now, but pay taxes on withdrawals later.
A pool of money from many investors to buy a variety of stocks, bonds, or other assets.
Spreading your money across different investments to reduce risk.
The profit made from selling something for more than you paid for it.
The original amount of money borrowed or invested, not including interest.
Life insurance that covers you for a specific period of time.
Life insurance that lasts your whole life and includes a savings part.
Flexible life insurance with a savings component and adjustable premiums.
The savings part of a permanent life insurance policy you can borrow from.
The person who receives the life insurance payout when you die.
The amount paid to your beneficiary when you die.
Life insurance features that let you access benefits while still alive, usually for illness.
A feature that lets you access your policy if you’re diagnosed with a long-term illness.
A feature that allows early access to life insurance if diagnosed with a terminal illness.
The fixed amount you pay for a medical service.
The amount you pay before your health insurance starts to cover costs.
The monthly cost you pay to keep your insurance active.
The most you’ll pay in a year for healthcare services.
An expense you can subtract from your income to lower your taxes.
An amount that reduces the taxes you owe, dollar for dollar.
A tax form your employer gives you that shows your income and taxes withheld.
A form you fill out to tell your employer how much tax to withhold from your paycheck.
The standard IRS tax form for filing personal income taxes.
A legal document that says who gets your stuff after you die.
A legal tool that holds and manages assets for someone else’s benefit.
A trust you can change or cancel during your lifetime.
A trust you cannot change once it's set up.
The person who carries out the instructions in your will.
A legal document letting someone make decisions for you if you can't.
A budgeting method where every dollar is assigned a job.
A cash-based method of budgeting by using envelopes for each spending category.
Money set aside for small, unexpected expenses.
A scheduled move of money between accounts to encourage saving.
The amount of money needed to cover basic expenses in a specific location.
A savings account with a higher-than-average interest rate.
A target you set for saving or spending money.
Increasing spending as your income rises.
Understanding basic financial principles and tools.
The money coming in and going out of your accounts.
Failure to repay a loan as agreed.
When a creditor hires a third party to collect unpaid debts.
A loan backed by collateral, like a car or house.
A loan not backed by any asset.
A loan repaid over time with a set number of payments.
Credit that renews as you pay it off, like a credit card.
The percentage of your credit limit you're using.
A credit check that can lower your score.
A credit check that doesn’t affect your score.
A temporary pause or reduction in loan payments.
A fund that tracks a specific market index.
An investment fund traded on stock exchanges.
A share of ownership in a company.
A loan to a company or government that pays interest.
An insurance product that pays out income, often in retirement.
A retirement plan that pays a set amount after retirement.
How your investments are divided among different types.
How much loss you’re willing to accept in investments.
The minimum amount you must withdraw from retirement accounts annually after age 73.
Moving funds from one retirement account to another.
The process insurers use to decide coverage and rates.
The person who owns the insurance policy.
An add-on to a life insurance policy for extra benefits.
The time when insurers can investigate and deny claims.
The end of a policy due to missed payments.
The amount the insurance will pay when you die.
A term policy that can be changed to permanent insurance.
You must benefit from the insured’s continued life.
Life insurance offered by an employer to employees.
A health check often required before issuing a policy.
Pays out if you’re diagnosed with a major illness like cancer.
Provides income if you become disabled and can’t work.
Covers care like a nursing home if you lose daily functions.
Pays part of the benefit if life expectancy is less than 12–24 months.
Refunds premiums if no claim is made by a certain time.
Stops your premium payments if you become disabled.
Life insurance meant to replace lost income.
Another name for early payout for serious illness.
Upfront access to a portion of the death benefit.
Pays out when you can’t perform two or more daily activities.
A savings account for medical expenses with tax advantages.
A tax-free account for out-of-pocket medical expenses.
A group of healthcare providers your insurance works with.
Healthcare services not covered by your insurance plan.
A doctor's recommendation to see a specialist.
Approval from insurance before a service is provided.
A cheaper version of a brand-name drug.
Insurance coverage for medication costs.
Remote access to doctors via phone or video.
Services like checkups to prevent illness.
Your income after certain adjustments, used for taxes.
Income that is subject to income tax.
A fixed amount that reduces your taxable income.
Specific expenses you list to lower your taxable income.
The range of income taxed at a specific rate.
Payroll tax that funds Social Security and Medicare.
Tax on profit from selling assets like stocks or real estate.
Taxes paid by freelancers or business owners for Social Security and Medicare.
Money your employer deducts from your paycheck for taxes.
Quarterly tax payments made if you're self-employed.
A document stating your medical wishes if you can’t communicate.
Someone you assign to make medical decisions for you.
Legal responsibility for a child or dependent person.
Everything you own at the time of your death.
Someone legally entitled to inherit property.
Dying without a legal will.
The court process of distributing your estate.
Person or institution managing the assets in a trust.
Written instructions about medical care preferences.
Tax paid by someone who inherits money or property.
A tax form used to provide your taxpayer identification number to someone who will pay you.
A tax form for reporting income earned outside of a regular job.
Income that is not taxed until a later date.
Someone you support financially and claim on your tax return.
Used to claim education credits like the American Opportunity Credit.
How quickly an asset can be turned into cash without losing value.
An increase in the value of an asset over time.
A decrease in the value of an asset over time.
A period of economic decline lasting at least two quarters.
Your total earnings before taxes or deductions.
Your earnings after taxes and deductions.
A financial report showing your income and expenses.
A summary of assets, liabilities, and net worth.
A measure of how much profit you earn from an investment.
A detailed report of your credit history.
The length of time you agree to repay a loan.
When you spend more than your account balance.
A service that prevents your account from going negative.
A nine-digit code used to identify your bank.
Your unique bank account identifier.
An electronic deposit of money directly into your account.
A method of electronically moving money between banks.
A fast, electronic transfer of funds across banks.
Depositing a check using a smartphone app.
A card that uses money directly from your bank account.
A summary of all your account activity over a period.
A business owned and operated by one person.
A Limited Liability Company, which protects your personal assets.
Credit established in a business's name, separate from personal credit.
Day-to-day expenses of running a business.
The percentage of revenue left after expenses.
When your revenue equals your expenses.
A bill sent to request payment for services or products.
Money owed to a business for goods or services.
Estimated tax payments made four times a year by self-employed people.
A permit allowing you to legally operate a business.
A professional who helps people manage their finances and plan for the future.
A person listed to be contacted in case of an emergency.
Online accounts or digital files with monetary or sentimental value.
What you leave behind for others, including money, property, or values.
Private insurance that helps cover costs not paid by Medicare.
The person named to receive benefits from insurance or accounts.
An upfront fee paid to secure services from a professional.
A financial arrangement where a third party holds funds until conditions are met.
A person who helps manage investments and finances.
When income exceeds expenses.
A legal agreement outlining what happens to a business if an owner leaves, retires, or dies.
A life insurance policy on an important person in a business to protect against their loss.
A flexible life insurance policy tied to a stock index with potential growth and downside protection.
An annuity that earns interest based on a market index but protects against market losses.
A financial product that provides a stream of payments in retirement, often for life.
Your total earnings before any deductions.
Your take-home pay after all deductions.
A claim that reduces the amount of income tax your employer withholds.
The recurring schedule your employer uses to pay you (e.g., biweekly).
The total of your earnings or deductions from the start of the year to now.
Taxes for Social Security and Medicare taken from your paycheck.
The money you choose to put into your retirement account from your paycheck.
Deductions made before taxes, like health insurance or retirement savings.
Deductions made after taxes, like union dues or garnishments.
Money a business owes to suppliers or vendors.
Money owed to a business by its customers.
A summary of income and expenses over a period.
Profit from business operations before interest and taxes.
Final earnings after all expenses and taxes.
Earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization.
A simpler version of the IRS 1040 tax form for basic returns.
A tax form for reporting income or loss from a sole proprietorship.
Shows your taxable wages, tips, and other compensation.
Shows the federal income tax withheld from your paycheck.
A form showing health insurance coverage from the marketplace.
A form showing mortgage interest paid, which may be tax-deductible.
A form that reports IRA contributions and rollovers.
A form that reports Social Security benefits received.
Used to itemize deductions like mortgage interest and medical expenses.
Used to report contributions to and distributions from a Health Savings Account (HSA).
A savings account with a fixed interest rate and term length.
A savings account that may offer higher interest rates and limited check writing.
The maximum amount you can borrow on a credit card.
The time when you’re not charged interest on a credit card balance.
A yearly charge for having a credit card or financial product.
A penalty for not making a payment on time.
Extra time granted to file your tax return, usually up to 6 months.
Used to request a tax filing extension from the IRS.
Non-cash benefits from employers that are considered taxable income.
Tax form used by tax-exempt organizations to provide financial information.
A government claim on your property due to unpaid taxes.
Owing more on an asset than it is currently worth.
Replacing an old loan with a new one with better terms.
Having enough income to cover living expenses without working.
Strategies used to protect wealth from lawsuits or creditors.
All the money, property, and other assets owned by a person at death.
An account that holds funds until contractual conditions are met.
A person authorized to witness signatures and administer oaths.
A legal right to keep possession of property until a debt is paid.
The legal process of repossessing property due to missed loan payments.
A legal process to eliminate or repay debt under court protection.
A registered name a business uses that is not its legal name.
A legally recognized organization formed to run a business.
A unique ID used by the IRS for business taxes.
Money used to start a business.
A short presentation used to communicate a business idea to investors.
A retirement plan for employees of public schools and certain nonprofits.
A retirement plan for government and nonprofit employees.
A retirement account for self-employed people and small business owners.
The maximum amount you can put into a retirement account each year.
Extra retirement savings allowed for people over age 50.
A policy you can get without medical questions or exams.
A life insurance policy that loses tax advantages due to overfunding.
Life insurance issued without a medical exam.
Rules used by insurance companies to approve or deny coverage.
The cash amount received if you cancel a life insurance policy early.
When expenses exceed income.
The value of what you give up when you make a choice.
Money today is worth more than the same amount in the future.
The rate you pay on your next dollar of income.
Interest calculated only on the original principal.
The outstanding amount still owed on a loan.
Regular payments made to repay a loan over time.
A contract to rent an asset for a specific period of time.
An asset pledged to secure a loan.
The rate at which prices increase over time.
Money held by a third party until terms of a contract are met.
A loan used to purchase a home or real estate.
The initial amount paid upfront when buying a home.
An estimate of a property's market value.
Fees paid at the end of a real estate transaction.
The value of a property minus the mortgage owed.
Insurance required if your down payment is less than 20%.
Protects against financial loss from defects in title to real property.
A legal document showing ownership of property.
Replacing an existing mortgage with a new one.
The length of time an insurance policy is in effect.
Extra time to pay a premium without losing coverage.
When coverage ends due to non-payment.
An add-on provision to enhance coverage.
What is not covered by the insurance policy.
A person who evaluates risk and determines policy terms.
The person who owns the insurance policy.
The cost you pay for insurance coverage.
The maximum amount an insurer will pay under a policy.
A request for payment based on an insurance policy.
